sub_topic: Calculation of Gibbs free energy change for a chemical reaction
message_1:
Sure, here's a question for the student to solve:

Calculate the Gibbs free energy change at 298 K for the reaction:

2HCl(g) + Na2CO3(s) → 2NaCl(s) + CO2(g) + H2O(g)

given the following information:

ΔH°f (kJ/mol)

HCl(g) = -92.31

Na2CO3(s) = -1130.98

NaCl(s) = -411.12

CO2(g) = -393.51

H2O(g) = -241.83

ΔS° (J/mol·K)

HCl(g) = 186.7

Na2CO3(s) = 51.1

NaCl(s) = 72.1

CO2(g) = 213.7

H2O(g) = 188.8
message_2:
To calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°) for the reaction, we can use the equation:

ΔG° = ΔH° - TΔS°

First, we need to find the change in enthalpy (ΔH°) and the change in entropy (ΔS°) for the reaction.

ΔH° = [Σ(ΔH°f products) - Σ(ΔH°f reactants)]

ΔH° = [2(-411.12) + (-393.51) + (-241.83)] - [2(-92.31) + (-1130.98)]

ΔH° = (-822.24 - 393.51 - 241.83) - (-184.62 - 1130.98)

ΔH° = -1457.58 + 1315.6

ΔH° = -141.98 kJ/mol

Now, we need to find the change in entropy (ΔS°):

ΔS° = [Σ(ΔS° products) - Σ(ΔS° reactants)]

ΔS° = [2(72.1) + 213.7 + 188.8] - [2(186.7) + 51.1]

ΔS° = (144.2 + 213.7 + 188.8) - (373.4 + 51.1)

ΔS° = 546.7 - 424.5

ΔS° = 122.2 J/mol·K

Now, we can calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°) using the equation:

ΔG° = ΔH° - TΔS°

ΔG° = -141.98 kJ/mol - (298 K)(122.2 J/mol·K)(1 kJ/1000 J)

ΔG° = -141.98 kJ/mol - (298 K)(0.1222 kJ/mol·K)

ΔG° = -141.98 kJ/mol - 36.42 kJ/mol

ΔG° = -178.4 kJ/mol

So, the Gibbs free energy change for the reaction at 298 K is -178.4 kJ/mol.
